ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Misophonia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Extreme emotional reactions (anger, rage) and physical discomfort to specific trigger sounds (chewing, eating, talking, silverware); MAQ score 51 (Extreme) and A-MISO-S score 19 (Severe) at baseline, worsening to MAQ 60 and A-MISO-S 21 at 1-year follow-up.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Decreased loudness tolerance with LDLs between 60-80 dB HL at baseline, significantly worsened to 35-50 dB HL at 1-year follow-up; patient reports physical discomfort to sounds.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine integrity of entire peripheral auditory system.
To evaluate loudness tolerance and screen for hyperacusis.

ordered_list.action: Tinnitus and Hyperacusis Initial Interview Form
ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine effects of sound sensitivity on patient well-being.
To quantify the severity and impact of misophonia and monitor progress.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient demonstrated normal peripheral hearing sensitivity and middle ear function bilaterally. Results indicated significant hyperacusis (reduced LDLs 60-80 dB HL vs. normal ~100 dB HL) and extreme misophonia (MAQ 51, A-MISO-S 19), with severe negative impact on daily life including self-mutilating behaviors. Acoustic reflexes could not be tested due to extreme sound hypersensitivity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally with PTA of 12 dB HL in each ear (250-20,000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 10 dB HL AU; WRS 96% (Right) and 100% (Left) at 50 dB HL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal middle ear function (Type A) bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Could not test (CNT) due to patient's extreme sound hypersensitivity.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.result_summary: Reduced loudness tolerance; Right ear: 60-70 dB HL, Left ear: 65-80 dB HL for pure tones; 75 dB HL for speech bilaterally.

tests.name: Tinnitus and Hyperacusis Initial Interview Form
tests.result_summary: Severity 9/10, Annoyance 10/10, Impact on quality of life 9-10/10.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Despite sound therapy intervention, patient showed significant worsening of both hyperacusis (LDLs markedly decreased to 35-50 dB HL) and misophonia (MAQ increased to 60, A-MISO-S to 21, both Extreme category). Patient was not consistently utilizing sound therapy. Behavioral observations confirmed severe functional impairment: unable to tolerate waiting room, removed upon arrival; 'triggered' on drive to clinic; communicated only via text message to parent. Pure-tone thresholds remained stable. Events leading to appointment may have contributed to decreased LDLs.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: No change in pure-tone air conduction thresholds at 250-20,000 Hz compared to baseline.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.result_summary: Markedly decreased; Right ear: 35-40 dB HL, Left ear: 40-50 dB HL for pure tones; Speech LDL 45 dB HL (Right), 40 dB HL (Left). Significant worsening from baseline.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.result_summary: MAQ score 60 (Extreme, increased from 51); A-MISO-S score 21 (Extreme, increased from 19).

proposed_items: Fit with bilateral Resound LINX2 5 receiver-in-the-canal (RIC) hearing aids programmed with 'water creek' sound therapy and no prescribed amplification.
Systematic program of sound therapy with gradual increase in exposure based on Jastreboff's TRT protocol.
Referral to psychologist or psychiatrist for evaluation and intervention.
As-needed follow-up visits for hearing aid maintenance.
counseling_actions: Counseling on the nature and management of misophonia and hyperacusis.
Instruction on using sound therapy devices: increase volume when most bothered by offending sounds, decrease when less bothered.
Recommendation for mental health intervention due to self-harm behaviors and obsessive thoughts/actions.

V2_revised_plan.treatment_status: Treatment failure - patient not compliant with sound therapy; no mental health intervention implemented
barriers_identified: Patient not consistently utilizing sound therapy devices.
Parents declined mental health referral due to concern about patient 'being labeled'.
Patient never prescribed medication or treatment plan for possible mental health disorder.
revised_proposed_items: Strongly reinforce consistent use of sound therapy devices immediately to prepare for college environment.
Re-discuss referral to psychologist or psychiatrist for evaluation of underlying psychological disorders.
Consider anxiety medication - advised parents to discuss with physician; medication could provide symptom relief.
Continue as-needed hearing aid maintenance visits.
counseling_actions: Discussed need for additional intervention to address possible underlying psychological disorders contributing to severity of sound sensitivities.
Discussed that anxiety medication could potentially provide symptom relief.
Extensive discussion of challenges JM may face in college: academic, social, and communal living settings.
Emphasized importance of consistent sound therapy use to be prepared for college environment.
Patient reported sound therapy helped when utilized with friends in noisy environments, but little improvement noted with trigger sounds around family.

red_flags_present: Self-mutilating behaviors: digging fingernails into backs of hands and scratching inside of wrists
Visible injuries noted at initial and follow-up appointments
Patient denied knowing how injuries occurred
Parent-reported history of anger and rage
Obsessive thoughts and actions (germ concern, meticulous about order/arrangement/process)

escalation_history.rationale_short: Patient exhibits self-mutilating behaviors, extreme rage in response to sounds, and obsessive thoughts/actions. Mental health screenings (BDI, HADS) not administered as parents unwilling to seek referral.
escalation_history.outcome: Parents declined referral due to concern about patient 'being labeled'.

escalation_history.destination: Psychologist or psychiatrist; Primary care physician for medication evaluation
escalation_history.rationale_short: Significant clinical deterioration despite intervention. Unable to tolerate waiting room, communicates only via text after triggering. LDLs and misophonia scores worsened substantially. Continued self-harm risk.
escalation_history.outcome: Pending - parents inquired about anxiety medication; advised to discuss with physician.

V1_plan.timeline: As-needed for hearing aid repairs and maintenance; 1 year for comprehensive re-evaluation
V1_plan.objective: Ensure sound therapy used consistently and hearing aids in good working order. Monitor hearing thresholds, LDLs, and misophonia severity.

V2_plan.timeline: Ongoing - as-needed basis; recommend closer monitoring given deterioration
V2_plan.objective: Continue monitoring; emphasize compliance with sound therapy before college transition. Reassess if patient/family willing to pursue mental health intervention. If no improvement with consistent sound therapy use, additional intervention modalities needed in conjunction with sound therapy and mental health referral.

expected_outcome: Pure-tone audiometry (1-year follow-up): Thresholds at 250 to 20,000 Hz revealed no change in pure-tone air conduction thresholds compared to baseline.
Loudness Discomfort Levels (1-year follow-up): Markedly decreased to levels between 35 and 50 dB HL in each ear, indicating worsened sound tolerance.
Misophonia Assessment Questionnaire (MAQ) (1-year follow-up): Total score of 60, placing patient in the extreme misophonia category.
Amsterdam Misophonia Scale (A-MISO-S) (1-year follow-up): Total score of 21, placing patient in the extreme misophonia category.
Patient was not consistently utilizing sound therapy and showed no measurable improvement in managing sound sensitivities.
Patient was visibly distressed during evaluation, unable to tolerate waiting room, and communicated only by text message.
Patient reported sound therapy helpful with friends in noisy environments when utilized, but little improvement with trigger sounds around family.
